facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1958 filed as appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 30, 1958 of Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by WANCHOO, J. on December 11, 1958

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This appeal by special leave raises the question of the constitutionality

facts.text: Appellant appointed to the Indian Police Service on October 1, 1949 and posted to the State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed to the Indian Police Service on October 1., 1949, and posted to the State of Punjab. He held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts

facts.text: Appellant held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts but reverted to Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957

anchor.surface_text: He held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts but was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957, and was eventually Posted to Dharamsala in March 1958.

facts.text: Appellant posted to Dharamsala in March 1958

anchor.surface_text: but was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957, and was eventually Posted to Dharamsala in March 1958. In the same month he was informed

facts.text: Appellant informed in March 1958 that action proposed against him under r. 5 of the All-India Services Discipline and Appeal Rules, 1955

anchor.surface_text: In the same month he was informed that it was proposed to take action against him under r. 5 of the All-India Services  Discipline and Appeal  Rules, 1955,  hereinafter called the Rules , framed under s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant placed under suspension under r. 7 of the Rules pending disciplinary proceedings

anchor.surface_text: He was thereafter -placed under suspension under r. 7 of the Rules pending disciplinary proceedings against him, and Shri K. L. Bhudiraja S. was appointed enquiry officer to hold the departmental enquiry against him.

facts.text: Shri K. L. Bhudiraja appointed enquiry officer to hold departmental enquiry against appellant

anchor.surface_text: pending disciplinary proceedings against him, and Shri K. L. Bhudiraja S. was appointed enquiry officer to hold the departmental enquiry against him. Notice was issued to him by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958.

facts.text: Notice issued to appellant by Enquiry Officer in July 1958

anchor.surface_text: Shri K. L. Bhudiraja S. was appointed enquiry officer to hold the departmental enquiry against him. Notice was issued to him by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958. He thereupon immediately made an application

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Art. 226 before Punjab High Court challenging constitutionality of the Act and legality of enquiry

anchor.surface_text: Notice was issued to him by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958. He thereupon immediately made an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the Punjab High Court challenging the constitutionality of the Act and the legality of the enquiry against him.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed the writ application on July 30, 1958

anchor.surface_text: the Punjab High Court challenging the constitutionality of the Act and the legality of the enquiry against him. The application was dismissed on July 30, 1958, and his application for a certificate to appeal to this Court was dismissed next day.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed appellant's application for certificate to appeal on July 31, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The application was dismissed on July 30, 1958, and his application for a certificate to appeal to this Court was dismissed next day. Thereupon he came to this Court and was granted special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant

facts.text: Indian Administrative Service and Indian Police Service deemed created by Parliament under Art. 312 at commencement of Constitution

Petitioner's suggested substitution in Art.312 (Council to provisional Parliament) would have been proper but omission exceeds power

anchor.surface_text: It is suggested that the adaptation would have been proper, if in Art. 312, as it originally stood in the Constitution, the words Council of States had been substituted by the words provisional Parliament , so that instead of a resolution of the Council of States a resolution of the provisional Parliament

court_response_anchor.surface_text: oned above from Art. 312 altogether. It is suggested that the adaptation would have been proper, if in Art. 312, as it originally stood in the Constit

arguments.court_reasoning: Art.392 leaves choice of adaptation method to President

holdings.text: The President's adaptation in Article 312 by omitting the Council of States resolution requirement under Article 392 via Constitution (Removal of Difficulties) Order No. II was not in excess of power.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Act cannot be declared unconstitutional on the ground that the President had exceeded his power under Art. 392 and that if he had not done so a resolution of the provisional Parliament would have been necessary with the requisite majority before any law could be undertaken to regulate the recruitment and the conditions of service of an all-India service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 392 authorizes adaptations by modification, addition, or omission to remove transition difficulties; President chose omission as expedient; Sankari Prasad affirms wide power without mandating specific form.

holdings.text: Provisional Parliament was competent to enact the All-India Services Act, 1951 without a prior resolution under Article 312 due to valid adaptation.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the adaptation made by the President in Art. 312 was within his power, there is very little left in the other two points raised by Mr. Chatterjee. It is said that the provisional Parliament was not competent to pass the Act in 1951, because the condition precedent for passing such a law had not been, as required by Art. 312, complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid adaptation removed condition precedent; Article 379 empowered provisional Parliament as full Parliament during transition.

holdings.text: The All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 are valid and not repugnant to Article 312 despite reappearance of omitted words.

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that the Rules were promulgated in 1955 when the words omitted by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II had reappeared in Art. 312 and were, therefore, repugnant to Art. 312 inasmuch as there was no resolution of the Council of States, as required by that Article, is, in our opinion, completely baseless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules derive validity from the permanent Act enacted validly; reappearance of Article 312 words post-order expiry does not invalidate rules.

holdings.text: Article 312 does not prohibit Parliament from delegating rule-making power for recruitment and conditions of service of all-India services.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot read Art. 312 as laying down a mandate prohibiting Parliament from delegating authority to the Central Government to frame rules for the recruitment and the conditions of service of all-India services. We, therefore, reject this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual prohibition on delegation; practical need for flexible rules; Delhi Laws Act permits delegation within limits.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the All-India Services Act, 1951 does not involve excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Act cannot be struck down on the ground of excessive delegation. Re. 6. The last contention is that the Punjab Government has no authority to institute these proceedings under the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 4 adopts pre-existing rules as policy/standard; Section 3 requires state consultation and parliamentary laying/modification; Delhi Laws provides framework.

holdings.text: Punjab Government has authority under the Rules to institute disciplinary enquiry against appellant serving in connection with its affairs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 5 institutes enquiry by government under which officer serving (Rule 2(b) defines as State Govt); Rule 4 limits major penalties to Central Govt post-enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Rajnarain Singh The Chairman. Patna Administration Committee, Patna 2

precedents.case_name: Rajnarain Singh v. Chairman, Patna Administration Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation held to go to the extent of authorising an executive authority to modify the law made but not in any essential feature

anchor.surface_text: Re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1

precedents.cited_proposition: essential legislative function consists in the determination or choosing of the legislative policy and of formally enacting that policy into a binding rule of conduct
precedents.cited_holding: The essential legislative function consists in the determination or choosing of the legislative policy and of formally enacting that policy into a binding rule of conduct. It is open to the legislature to formulate the policy as broadly and with as little or as much details as it thinks proper and it may delegate the rest of the legislative work to a subordinate authority who will work out the details within the framework of that policy.

anchor.surface_text: This contention must also be rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: All six contentions of the appellant rejected. President's adaptation under Art. 392 upheld. All-India Services Act, 1951 held valid. Delegation under s. 3 not excessive. Rules valid. Punjab Government competent to institute disciplinary enquiry under the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Act cannot be declared unconstitutional on the ground that the President had exceeded his power under Art. 392 and that if he had not done so a resolution of the provisional Parliament would have been necessary with the requisite majority before any law could be undertaken to regulate the recruitment and the conditions of service of an all-India service.
This contention must also be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the adaptation made by the President in Art. 312 was within his power, there is very little left in the other two points raised by Mr. Chatterjee. It is said that the provisional Parliament was not competent to pass the Act in 1951, because the condition precedent for passing such a law had not been, as required by Art. 312, complied with.
This contention must also be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that the Rules were promulgated in 1955 when the words omitted by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II had reappeared in Art. 312 and were, therefore, repugnant to Art. 312 inasmuch as there was no resolution of the Council of States, as required by that Article, is, in our opinion, completely baseless.
This contention must also be rejected.

We cannot read Art. 312 as laying down a mandate prohibiting Parliament from delegating authority to the Central Government to frame rules for the recruitment and the conditions of service of all-India services. We, therefore, reject this contention.
This contention must also be rejected.
